verses.text: Remember, O LORD, what has happened to us; look, and see our disgrace.
verses.comment: The opening plea recalls the tradition of calling on the LORD to look upon the suffering of His people, as in the Psalms. This introduces the theme of lament and confidence in God's providential care.

verses.text: Our inheritance has been given over to strangers, our homes to foreigners.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the loss of land and displacement, fulfillment of warnings given in the Law (Deuteronomy). The inheritance in the Old Testament points toward a spiritual inheritance in Christ (see Eph. 1:11).

verses.text: We have become orphans, fatherless; our mothers are like widows.
verses.comment: The imagery of orphans and widows conveys utter vulnerability and need—spiritually, the faithful call God 'Father' and find protection in His household (see Jas. 1:27).

verses.text: We must pay for the water we drink, and our wood comes at a price.
verses.comment: What was once freely provided in the land now becomes difficult to attain. This anticipates humanity's need for God's freely-given grace and living water (see Jn. 4:10).

verses.text: We are pursued at our heels; we are weary, and have no rest.
verses.comment: The longing for rest is ultimately fulfilled in Christ, who offers spiritual rest to the weary. The lack of rest reflects Israel’s separation from God’s presence.

verses.text: We have stretched out our hands to Egypt and to Assyria, to get enough bread.
verses.comment: Seeking help from foreign nations rather than trusting God. The spiritual lesson teaches reliance on God’s providence, not worldly alliances.

verses.text: Our ancestors sinned, and they are no more; but we bear their iniquities.
verses.comment: Echoes the doctrine of generational consequences for sin (see Exodus 34:7), but also points toward hope in personal responsibility and redemption (Jer. 31:29-30).

verses.text: Servants rule over us; there is no one to deliver us from their hand.
verses.comment: Reversal of fortune: the people once chosen by God are now under subjugation. Spiritually, all humanity needs a Redeemer to deliver from bondage.

verses.text: We get our bread at the risk of our lives, because of the sword in the wilderness.
verses.comment: Echoes the curses for covenant unfaithfulness—security and daily bread become threatened. 'Sword in the wilderness' highlights the constant danger of exile.

verses.text: Our skin is hot as an oven because of the burning heat of famine.
verses.comment: The suffering is vivid and physical. Deeper spiritual symbolism points toward the judgment and purifying fire—famine often representing spiritual emptiness.

verses.text: Women are violated in Zion, virgins in the towns of Judah.
verses.comment: This grave suffering signals both physical and spiritual devastation—a call for mercy and restoration. The Church later sees in such suffering a call to compassion and protection for the vulnerable.

verses.text: Princes are hung up by their hands; elders are shown no respect.
verses.comment: Social order and reverence for leaders are destroyed—reflecting the consequences of abandoning divine authority and tradition.

verses.text: Young men are compelled to grind at the mill, and boys stagger under loads of wood.
verses.comment: Forced labor underscores the total humiliation of the people. Thematically, it points to sin’s capacity to enslave, contrasted to the freedom Christ brings.

verses.text: The elders have left the gate, the young men their music.
verses.comment: Loss of community leadership and joy, representing spiritual desolation. The 'gate' symbolized justice and guidance, now absent, pointing toward the need for restored order.

verses.text: Joy has left our hearts; our dancing has turned to mourning.
verses.comment: Sorrow replaces joy, echoing the reversal themes in Scripture. God alone can turn mourning to joy—a messianic anticipation fulfilled in the ministry of Jesus.

verses.text: The crown has fallen from our head. Woe to us, for we have sinned!
verses.comment: Loss of the crown denotes the loss of God’s ordained kingship; confession of sin paves the way for forgiveness and restoration. Confession is always the first step toward reconciliation.

verses.text: Because of this our hearts are sick; because of these things our eyes grow dim,
verses.comment: Sorrow here is both emotional and spiritual—repentance and sorrow over sin prepares the heart for God’s healing and light.

verses.text: for Mount Zion lies desolate; jackals prowl over it.
verses.comment: Zion as the holy place is now laid waste, a visible sign of divine judgment and the sadness of ruined worship—an invitation to long for true restoration.

verses.text: But You, O LORD, are enthroned forever; Your throne endures from generation to generation.
verses.comment: A shift from lament to hope: even amid disaster, God’s kingship and faithfulness are affirmed. The eternal throne foreshadows Christ’s everlasting reign (see Heb. 1:8).

verses.text: Why do You forget us forever, why do You forsake us for so long?
verses.comment: Echoes the cry of abandonment, famously prayed by Christ on the cross (Matt. 27:46), expressing deep identification with human suffering.

verses.text: Turn us back to Yourself, O LORD, and we will return; renew our days as of old—
verses.comment: A prayer for conversion and restoration; emphasizes that even repentance is by God's grace. This repeated theme in the Prophets is reflected in New Testament teachings on grace and restoration (see Lk. 15:20).

verses.text: unless You have utterly rejected us, and are exceedingly angry with us.
verses.comment: A somber end, lingering between despair and hope. The tradition reads this as a call never to give up seeking God's mercy—trusting in His final redemption. In liturgical practice, verse 21 is often repeated after this, emphasizing hope over despair.
